Nicola and Chad Johns of Roseville, California, believe the nation's product recall system is broken.
Here's why.
In April of 2005, they put their 9-month-old baby boy, Liam, to bed in a crib.
Everything seemed normal until the next morning when Nicola went back to her son's room.
I saw my son hanging from the crib.
His neck basically caught at the mattress.
So his chin was resting on the mattress and the rest of his body was hanging straight down.
The crib was made in China by Pennsylvania-based Simplicity Inc., also marketed as Graco.
Like many cribs, it had one side that could drop down to make it easier to reach the baby.
In this crib, that drop side came loose, allowing Liam's neck to get wedged between the side and the mattress.
When I pulled him out of the crib, he was not breathing.
And we gave him CPR until the paramedics came.
And he was pronounced dead at the hospital.
He was 9 months old.
Liam's death prompted Nicola and Chad Johns to file suit against Simplicity Inc. They argued that a design flaw and unclear assembly instructions created the deadly hazard.
Their lawyer, Charles Kelly, alerted the Consumer Product Safety Commission, the CPSC, of the danger.
I alerted the CPSC in June of 2005, two months after Liam's death, and it wasn't until over two years later that they sent a field investigator to come and look at the crib and take it away.
By then, the cribs had killed two more babies, temporarily trapped seven others and prompted more than 50 complaints.
Finally, this past September, two and a half years after Liam Johns death, the CPSC and Simplicity recalled 1 million cribs, the largest crib recall ever.
